Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Tropical Forests Today: Reproduction and Conservation In the Face of Global Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will synthesize knowledge about the reproductive biology of tropical forest trees. The synthesis will incorporate recent ideas and data, update previous findings, and review the impact of contemporary global environmental changes such as land use change, the spread of invasive species, and climate change. This review will help define future trends in reproduction and regeneration in tropical forests, and assess the effects of these trends for sustaining tropical biodiversity.

The results of this synthesis will be of interest to a wide range of biologists, and foster new research on reproduction and regeneration of plants in tropical forests. The work on the effects of global environmental change on the reproduction and population biology of forest trees, and the possibilities for mitigating these effects, will help conservation biologists, resource managers, and policy makers. It will offer opportunities for graduate students to participate in the synthesis of concepts and data, meta-analyses, and the linking of fundamental research with issues of human use of natural resources, land management, and conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Outcomes: The two major goals were to: a) undertake a synthesis of a range of current concepts and data on reproductive traits of tropical forest trees to test some basic hypotheses about the evolution of breeding systems, pollination mechanisms, seed dispersal, population genetic structure, and of such traits as polyploidy and apomixes, and b) link my earlier work on reproductive traits with today?s challenges to the sustainable management of tropical forests. Even though the project is over, the work on these two goals is continuing. Major outputs so far include two papers on kin selection published in peer-reviewed journals. Kin selection refers to the sacrifice of the individual to enhance the fitness of its close relatives. Our results indicate that kin selection may have led to two types of flowering plants, plants with large flowers pollinated by specialized pollinators and having multi-seeded fruits in which all or most seeds are from a single pollen parent. The other group has small flowers, generalist pollinators, and single or few seed fruits. In addition to three papers on kin selection, two more papers were published on the evolution of certain reproductive traits in plants. Two additional papers were published on policies related to research in biodiversity. Just last week, I have been approached by Research Outreach, to allow them to write a popular article on our work that demonstrates the possible existence of two types of distinct reproductive strategies in flowering plants.

 

Wider Impacts: Although this OPUS grant was primarily for synthesis of data, and the outcomes were intended to be largely intellectual or academic, four wider impacts were made. The first dealt with strengthening human resources in the field of population biology. One postdoctoral student and one graduate student were mentored and engaged in the project. Each co-authored two papers with me. Second, a wider scholarly community was involved in reviewing the broader field of kin selection and kin communication. At the end of the project, an international symposium was organized on October 5 and 6, 2019, to review recent research on kin selection and kin cooperation and identify emerging questions. The papers presented at the symposium will be published as a special collection in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, and as an e-book. Third, during the grant period, the PI also continued his work on the sustainability of tropical biodiversity in general and tropical forests in particular and published two commentaries, one in Science and the other in PNAS targeted at scientists, policy makers and general readers. Finally, two Op-Ed pieces, on the global decline of pollinators and another on biodiversity and ecosystem services,  were published in India?s leading newspaper, The Hindu, to inform thousands, if not millions of citizens.
